results.title: The Moat monster
results.creator_credit: Steve Campus Productions and Sara H Arnaud
results.brief_description: Infantile anxieties embodied in the apocryphal Moat Monster. Extraordinary document of unrestrained play, profiling a small group of pre-school children and the spontaneous generation of their narrative about the ‘Moat Monster’. Contingent nature of children’s reality finds expression in the creative dynamism of this whimsical drama. Portions of this film appear in a full length film entitled ‘Role Enactment in Children’s Play: a Developmental Overview’. Episode 3 of “Training module on role enactment in children’s play” series.

results.title: The Mississippi River: background for social studies
results.brief_description: Follows a houseboat down the Mississippi River, explaining that the river and its tributaries form a vast network of waterways, linking great agricultural and industrial areas with important cities and ports. The importance of the Mississippi as a drainage basin for more than a third of the continent; its geographic, commercial and historic influence on adjacent lands.

results.title: The Mission (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Puttnam, Fernando Ghia and Roland Joffe
results.brief_description: A man of the sword. A man of the cloth. A clash of civilisations. A fight to the death. A political parable and portrait of 18th century missionary works. Shot on location in the breathtaking jungles of South America. “The Mission” is a movie experience to be shared by all. Stars Robert de Niro and Jeremy Irons.

results.title: The Missing interest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Office Supervisor’s Problem”.
A dramatised case problem which can lead to searching discussion of methods of developing employee involvement and interest in low level narrow scope jobs. Supervisors can identify and project themselves into the situation. The film poses but does not answer a basic problem.

results.title: The Misfits
results.creator_credit: Seven Arts, United Artists Corporation, Frank E Taylor and John Huston
results.brief_description: In the gambling desert town of Reno, a recently divorced young woman falls for an ageing cowboy. They slowly begin to build a life together but the chance arrival of a younger cowboy, and the older man’s obsession with his romantic memories of the “old West”, threaten to destroy the relationship. A collaboration between New York playwright Arthur Miller and director John Huston, “The Misfits” examines the increasing commercialisation and subsequent alienation of contemporary life by modernising the most traditional of Hollywood genres: the Western. The film stars Marilyn Monroe, Montgomery Clift and Clark Gable in three superb performances. Intense and involving, “The Misfits” also stars Thelma Ritter and Eli Wallach.

results.title: The Mirror of paradoxes: self-portraits, Rembrandt Van Rijn
results.creator_credit: La Sept, FR3, Delta Image, Musée du Louvre and Alain Jaubert
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Rembrandt created almost one hundred self-portraits from the age of twenty to the age of sixty-three. This program looks at a selection of these in detail, discussing his technique, how it differed from others’ painting at the same time, at some of the possible symbolism of the costumes and props he used and at outside influences on his art. An American version of a French production.
results.title_for_label: The Mirror of paradoxes: self-portraits, Rembrandt Van Rijn

results.title: The Mirror of man
results.brief_description: A statement on behalf of contemporary art. Presents the movement from the first break with classical form to our art expression of today. Paintings used in the film were selected from the 1958 Retrospective Exhibition at the Carnegie Institute at Pittsburgh, which presented a survey of paintings shown at the International Exhibitions of the Institute since 1894. Commentator: Vincent Price

results.title: The Mirror [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.brief_description: After her mother fails to pick her up after school, a young Iranian girl with a broken arm (Mina Mohammed-Khani) sets off to find her own way home. As she traverses the bustling streets of Tehran, clogged with the press of people, traffic, and noise, she grows increasingly uncertain of her direction and the correct route. The everyday sounds, movements and interactions of city life are conveyed through her experiences as she encounters strangers both helpful and indifferent, rides on buses, and is confronted with rules regarding male and female behaviour. Midway through, the film takes a startling turn that breaks the audience’s engagement with the narrative and throws the constructed nature of this naturalistic documentation of city life into relief. The actor playing the young girl suddenly abandons her character declaring that she has had enough of acting and wants to go home. As she leaves the set the crew decide to keep filming as she undergoes a process almost identical to that of her character in her attempts to find her way home on her own. Rather than functioning as a distancing device, this shift offers an alternate version of a reality mediated by cinema. The focus on the filmmaking process itself and the use of non-actors and children in lead roles are all characteristic hallmarks of recent Iranian cinema. In Farsi with English subtitles.
